docs.title: Biography
docs.text:
I am a PhD student at Carnegie Mellon University advised by Prof. Anthony Rowe and Prof. Ben Titzer. I am interested in cross-cutting computer systems research, spanning areas of virtualization, operating systems, and compilers with an embedded systems flavor. My current research direction investigates harnessing bytecode virtualization, particularly WebAssembly, to unlock safe deployment and debuggability in resource-constrained cyber-physical edge systems.

I enjoy low-level systems design, and have built custom out-of-order RISC-V CPU, an FPGA, and participated in numerous hackathons-style events. Career goals aside, I am an avid rock climber, biker, surfer, and hiker. Playing the guitar and piano is a fairly great escape from the day to day. With a passion for travelling, I live spontaneously and enjoy embracing elements from many cultures, including my Indian and American roots.

docs.title: Empowering WebAssembly with Thin Kernel Interfaces
docs.text:
Arjun Ramesh, Tianshu Huang, Ben L. Titzer, Anthony Rowe

Webassembly (Wasm) adoption for new domains is often hindered by the lack of standard system interfaces. Kernel interface support in Wasm engines allow numerous languages and applications to target Wasm, including arbitrary high-level Wasm APIs (WASI), driving ISA portability and software safety down to even deeply embedded OS ecosystems

EuroSys 2025 Pre-Print WALI Rust Target

docs.title: Unveiling Heisenbugs with Diversified Execution
docs.text:
Arjun Ramesh, Tianshu Huang, Jaspreet Riar, Ben L. Titzer, Anthony Rowe

The detection of quirky Heisenbugs are influenced by numerous factors including (but not limited to) hardware platforms and, strangely, the extent of instrumentation used by debuggers themselves. We propose a debugging methodology that harnesses diversity across platforms and the debugger's instrumentation to enable low-overhead debugging at scale. Skim our paper for a characterization of over 100 numerous funky bug behaviors!

OOPSLA 2025 Data Artifact

docs.title: Silverline: Lightweight Virtualization and Orchestration of Distributed Systems
docs.text:
Arjun Ramesh, Tianshu Huang, Emily Ruppel, Dakshina Dasari, Behnaz Pourmohseni, Fedor Smirnov, Marco Giani, Paolo Pazzaglia, Charles Shelton, Nuno Pereira, Arne Hamann, Dirk Ziegenbein, Anthony Rowe

Real-time cyber-physical systems naturally lend themselves to distributed compute, but are often programmed monolithically to curb complexity and safety exploits. Our framework, Silverline, explores programmability and orchestration of distributed applications transparently across wide range of hardware using WebAssembly for lightweight virtualization.

RTAS 2025 Silverline Org

docs.title: Interference-aware Edge Runtime Prediction with Conformal Matrix Completion
docs.text:
Tianshu Huang, Arjun Ramesh, Emily Ruppel, Nuno Pereira, Anthony Rowe, Carlee Joe-Wong

Performance prediction in heterogeneous edge computing systems is critical for effective resource allocation and cost optimization. We formulate this problem as matrix completion, which can be extended to handle complex, edge-specific concerns such as interference and uncertainty quantification accurately.

MLSys 2025
